Award.AwardTitle: Interactive Mentoring Activities for Under-Represented Minority Faculty

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology will direct a career development and mentoring program called Interactive Mentoring Activities for Grantsmanship Enhancement (IMAGE). IMAGE was developed because there is a serious lack of faculty development programs that target under-represented minority faculty, particularly senior postdoctoral scientists and early-stage Assistant Professors. The IMAGE program seeks to increase the number of federally-funded junior faculty, particularly members of groups that are under-represented in STEM disciplines and faculty that teach at minority serving institutions. Given that a key element of a sustainable academic career in the sciences is extramural funding, developing tenable strategies to improve the success rates of under-represented minority faculty in securing funding is a critical component in increasing the number of under-represented minorities in academia. IMAGE will offer annual mentoring workshops and one-on-one structured mentoring. In addition, IMAGE will provide a web-based interactive resource for dissemination of grant writing and career development resources, as well as for mentoring. This online resource will make information obtained through the IMAGE program widely available to a broad audience.

The IMAGE program will provide intensive mentoring on grantsmanship skills and career development strategies over a three-year period. Senior postdoctoral scientists and early-stage Assistant Professors from groups under-represented in science will attend annual mentoring workshops focusing on grant-writing, peer mentoring, and career development advice, as well as receiving one-on-one structured mentoring where each participant will be paired with a senior, successful scientist who has a strong track record of securing federal funding. Best practices and other resources generated through the IMAGE program will be made widely available through the development of an online web-based resource. The IMAGE program has the following specific aims: 1) To organize an annual grant-writing and mentoring workshop for Junior Faculty and Postdoctoral Fellows. 2) To provide one-on-one mentoring in the preparation and submission of a competitive NSF grant application. 3) To provide postdoctoral mentees with effective strategies for obtaining a faculty position. 4) To develop a curated web-based resource for use by postdoctoral fellows and faculty.

This award is supported jointly by Programs in the Chemistry of Life Processes (Division of Chemistry) and Molecular Biophysics (Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences).

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

 

The Minority Affairs Committee (MAC) of the American Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (ASBMB) was awarded a grant from the National Science Foundation to study the impact of intensive mentoring and grant-writing workshops on the ability of pre-tenured faculty to receive federal funding, especially those from underrepresented ethnic groups or minority serving institutions. From 2015 to 2019, ASBMB MAC held 2 ½ day workshops on grant-writing as one aspect of a mentoring program called Interactive Mentoring AND Grantsmanship Enhancement (IMAGE). These workshops convened up to 32 pre-tenured faculty, postdoctoral associates and other research scientists per year to interact with established grant-writers who served as mentors. Each workshop featured lectures from NSF and National Institutes of Health (NIH) program directors on navigating the funding process at their agencies and lectures about the details of and best practices associated with grant-writing for each of these agencies by established and highly successful investigators, as well as by previous participants of the program who received funding. In addition, NSF- and NIH-style mock grant-review panels were held to show attendees the details associated with the reviewing of proposals. Lastly, each participant was given 20-min to deliver an oral presentation on the details of a proposal that they planned to submit. In the 10 min that followed the presentation, feedback on their ideas was provided by the mentors and other attendees. Other elements of the workshop included presentations or group discussions on 1) laboratory management and motivating students; 2) establishing fruitful collaborations and resolving conflicts; and 3) balancing teaching, research and service. Over the five-year period, the workshop served 144 participants, of which 77 were female and 67 were male, while 33 (23%) were from underrepresented ethnic groups in science and 26 were postdoctoral associates or others who were not tenure-track faculty members. 

 

BROADER IMPACTS

 

One aim of this award was to provide extensive evaluation of the program. To that end, each participant in each yearly cohort was matched with a comparison individual who did not participate in the IMAGE program or any other dedicated grant-writing program. Each IMAGE participant and his or her match was tracked across time to assess his or her scholarly productivity, success in securing extramural funding, and successful progression through the tenure and promotion process. Our results from the early three cohorts (2015 -2017) showed that IMAGE participants and their matched controls each submitted a proposal at about the same frequency; however, the IMAGE participants were more than two-fold more likely to received funding! Other measures of the success of the program include feedback from surveys provided to the participants. The overwhelming majority (greater than 95%) of the respondents (greater than 90% response rate) rated their overall experience at the grant-writing workshop as very positive and the feedback that they received to be constructive or very constructive. Twelve of the 30 attendees in the 2015 cohort received one or more awards from NSF and/or NIH, which represents a 40% cumulative success rate over about 4 years. Of these 12, five were underrepresented minority scientists or from minority serving institutions. The success rates for the 2013 and 2014 cohorts (not covered by this award) are even higher. Most of the attendees who did not obtain NSF or NIH funding were from universities that were not research intensive.
